"**Lookin ' for Love**" is a song written by Wanda Mallette, Bob Morrison and
Patti Ryan, and recorded by American country music singer [Johnny
Lee](/wiki/Johnny_Lee_\(singer\) "Johnny Lee \(singer\)"). It was released in
June 1980 as part of the soundtrack to the film _[Urban
Cowboy](/wiki/Urban_Cowboy "Urban Cowboy")_ , released that year. [Marcy
Levy](/wiki/Marcy_Levy "Marcy Levy") was one of the female singers who
provided backing vocals on the track.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lookin%27_for_Love&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

Lee whose biggest hit to date had been a 1977 cover of Ricky Nelson's "[Garden
Party](/wiki/Garden_Party_\(Rick_Nelson\) "Garden Party \(Rick Nelson\)")" had
previously been one of the main nightclub acts at Gilley's, a nightclub owned
by country music superstar [Mickey Gilley](/wiki/Mickey_Gilley "Mickey
Gilley"). Record executive Irving Azoff offered Lee the chance to record
"Lookin' For Love", a song that 20-plus artists had rejected.[1]

Critics were not kind to Lee nor the song. Country music historian Bill Malone
once noted that "Lookin' for Love"—in his words, a "lilting little pop song" —
became the featured song of _Urban Cowboy_ and a huge commercial hit largely
because "actor [John Travolta](/wiki/John_Travolta "John Travolta") (the
movie's co-star) expressed a liking for it."[2] Critic Kurt Wolff panned the
song as an example of "watered-down cowboy music."[3]

Public reaction was much better. "Lookin' for Love" rose to No. 1 (for a
three-week stay) on the _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard
\(magazine\)")_ [Hot Country Singles](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country
Songs") chart, and was a No. 5 [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100
"Billboard Hot 100") hit as well. On the US _[Cash
Box](/wiki/Cash_Box_\(magazine\) "Cash Box \(magazine\)")_ Top 100, the song
spent two weeks at No. 4.[4]

"Lookin' for Love" was certified gold for sales of 1 million units by the
[Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America").[5]

## Series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lookin%27_for_Love&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Series")]

The song was performed by Johnny Lee in an episode of _[Chips](/wiki/CHiPs
"CHiPs")_. It could also be heard in two episodes of
[Dallas](/wiki/Dallas_\(1978_TV_series\) "Dallas \(1978 TV series\)"). The
first one is episode 274 "To Have and to Hold", where it plays at the bar
where Bobby Ewing and Kay Lloyd are enjoying each other's company. The second
episode is episode 275 "Dead Reckoning", where Ray Krebbs listens to it on his
car stereo after dropping off his wife Jenna and her daughter Charlie at the
airport.

## Cover versions, parodies and
tributes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lookin%27_for_Love&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Cover versions, parodies and tributes")]

Country music group [Sawyer Brown](/wiki/Sawyer_Brown "Sawyer Brown") recorded
a cover of the song on the 2000 album _[The Hits Live](/wiki/The_Hits_Live
"The Hits Live")_. This version peaked at No. 44 on the _Billboard_ [Hot
Country Singles & Tracks](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs") chart.
The song is also featured in the classic _[Saturday Night
Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ sketch _Buh-Weet
Sings_ , in which [Buckwheat](/wiki/Billie_Thomas "Billie Thomas") from _[Our
Gang](/wiki/Our_Gang "Our Gang")_ (played by [Eddie Murphy](/wiki/Eddie_Murphy
"Eddie Murphy")) sings the song as "Wookin Pa Nub".

The _[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Deep_Space_Nine "Star Trek:
Deep Space Nine")_ episode "[Looking for par'Mach in All the Wrong
Places](/wiki/Looking_for_par%27Mach_in_All_the_Wrong_Places "Looking for
par'Mach in All the Wrong Places")" is titled in tribute to this song ("_par
'Mach_" is defined in the episode as "the [Klingon](/wiki/Klingon_language
"Klingon language") word for love, but with more aggressive overtones").[10]

[Al Lowe](/wiki/Al_Lowe "Al Lowe")'s second _[Leisure Suit
Larry](/wiki/Leisure_Suit_Larry "Leisure Suit Larry")_ game, _[Leisure Suit
Larry Goes Looking for Love (in Several Wrong
Places)](/wiki/Leisure_Suit_Larry_Goes_Looking_for_Love_\(in_Several_Wrong_Places\)
"Leisure Suit Larry Goes Looking for Love \(in Several Wrong Places\)")_ , is
named after the song. The song was referenced in _[Operation
Repo](/wiki/Operation_Repo "Operation Repo")_ in season 11 episode 7.

The Mexican group, Los Felinos did a Spanish cover "Buscando Amor."
